reviews.review_msg: I took this class in Fall 2019 and he was horrible. I went to office hours to get extra help since our TA had a family emergency. He laughed at me as I asked questions and told me to figure it out. Not sure what I could use to "figure it out" when there's no slides/textbook, only his three hour long lectures where he says ambiguous a million times.

I would never take this professor again. He acts like everyone knows what he's talking about and he is really hesitant to provide help. I reached out to him to see how he could provide extra help and he told me to order a book called "How to learn better" on Amazon. DO NOT TAKE

He DOES NOT have lecture slides. He gets up there and talks for two hours straight and you better be taking notes. But otherwise, cool prof, cool course, and it teacher you a lot about how to read and interpret research articles.

Prof was understanding with late penalties and deadlines when COVID-19 hit. Good lecturer, interesting material. Assignments were straightforward, short, & easy. Would definitely recommended taking him for social psychology.

took this class spring 2020 during covid-19. prof. wright was super understanding about the situation and very helpful. lectures had slides that were posted but most only had pics, you spend the whole lecturing writing notes and there isn't a textbook. Not my favorite since I'm bad at taking good notes quickly, but the prof himself was nice
Was generous with grades and understanding about the mid semester switch to online format.

Good lectures and I enjoyed not having to buy an expensive textbook. Not having one does save money but also means attending every class is important. The cancelling of the final exam made it difficult to make up for my midterm grade but Dr. Wright did add a free letter grade to make up for the bumpy online transition.

Dr. Wright was really kind and understanding when I contacted him about my illness. I found the course entertaining informative, though the course was negatively impacted by the sudden move to the online format. I went to see Dr. Wright a few times in office hours and he was incredibly helpful and encouraging of my future career.

His lectures are absolutely amazing--he hardly skips a beat going through the material. He gives a lot of examples of concepts and theories. He gives "collective extra credit" during the lecture on prosocial behavior, which is nice because the course is challenging for a second year class.

Prof Wright isn't the worst prof you could get by any means. His lectures were quite interesting, tho they were very heavy and he talks fast, so you have to be a good note-taker. He does carry a bit of a haughty air and was unnecessarily rude to me after I inquired about what I *still* think was an unfair grade. Was not easy for an 'intro' class.

I dont enjoy his style. He seems like a very intelligent guy but Im not sure that he enjoys teaching. Seems to have a know it all attitude about some things. If you take this course make sure you have something to type on because there barely any slides, most of what u learn will be based on what he says.

The lecture slides and the lecture itself was very difficult to follow along to, so be prepared to go back and listen to the 3 hour long lecture to take notes that actually make sense. Treat this course as if it's an upper division course, the TAs mark harshly and due to the fact that you need to know what's important/unimportant. Avoid if you can

A lot of ppl hated his tough grading bc he taught an intro course like an upper-div class. I personally enjoyed the class because it challenged me/made me into a better reader/writer. Went to office hours and he gave me gr8 advice so I felt more prepared to take psyc 300w. Hes rly nice in office hours! Exam (MC/SA) is easy if u study & do readings

Worst prof I have had at SFU in 4 years. Absolutely no structure to the course. No textbook and garbage powerpoint slides so it is very unclear what you should be focused on learning. Overly hard grader and will try to screw you over if he marks your paper. Under no circumstance would I recommend you taking this course with him. Terrible

AVOID THIS PROF AT ALL COSTS. He provides no materials for the entire course. Marking for assignments was unclear & unfair, average was 58%. In order to pass this course, each week I listened to his 3 hour audio lecture (which took more like 5 hours) to get accurate notes. This course made me question if I wanted to peruse social psychology.

A decent prof at the beginning of the semester but slowly he becomes your worst nightmare. Made it impossible to follow lectures in class, a waste of time to attend when you can listen to audio recordings later. Poor attitude and useless to access him during office hours, he' unwilling to provide help but rather make snarky comments. NO NOT TAKE!!!

He talks extremely fast so I had to re-listen to every lecture to take complete notes. There is no textbook and very few readings. If you study the lecture notes you'll do well on tests. Two assignments that were fairly marked.
Pretty cool course. The content is interesting and it's not a difficult class.

Joshua Wright is a great professor. He is passionate about what he teaches. He isn't the traditional type, but if you show up, listen, and take notes you'll do well. He isn't going to spoon feed the information, but if you engage with the material on a critical level you'll do well. Not too much work required, and text book isn't mandatory.

He talks way too fast in class, and had no notes up. If you missed what he said, hopefully your friend next to you heard. I did better in my final when I simply didnt go to class and listened to the lectures online, that way I can go back and write down what he said.
One of the few classes I actually enjoyed going to, he's great at making lectures engaging although talks quite fast.

Great public speaker but very off topic (taught mainly stats and critical analysis in a social psych class) I do not feel like I learned what I should have for 260. No required textbook. Projects had vague criteria making it hard to do well on them. Take detailed notes his slides are mostly blank. Not GPA booster. Added bonus he's nice to look at.

Dr. Wright is unlike other boring professors. The way he teaches makes you think critically about social psychology. You are actually learning a lot when you listen to his engaging lectures. Its not an easy class but nothing is easy in life. If you attend his lectures and take notes, you should excel in his class. The info you learn is long term.

He is a good lecturer. However, his teachings are more suited for an upper division class which can be unfair to some students. You HAVE to take good notes in class because his lec slides contain barely any info. Be sure to re-listen to the lec recordings if you miss anything. It really helps!

I liked the critical thinking approach he takes to concepts, you wont just memorize definitions. forces you to think. not an easy class but if you are actually interested in psychology it's worth it. gave great lectures that were posted online, and no participation marks so attendance not mandatory. PSA don't buy the textbook!

Dr. Wright gives amazing lectures. He lectures pretty fast and sometimes its hard to follow through. If you skip class, slides with ont be helpful. Lectures are recorded. He gave us 3 assignments to complete during the semester, midterm exam was difficult. Overall, this class seems like an upper division class or statistical research.
Dr. Wright is very knowledgeable and he is a good lecturer.

Overall, a good lecturer but is probably better suited for upper division course as he doesn't teach this course at an introductory level which isn't fair as a lot of students will go in expecting to learn more than they will.
Amazing professor.

Probably a love it or hate type course. Makes you work for your grade w/ some short writing assignments and two exams with short answers. Requires reading of articles but no textbook. Must take good notes to do well. What's good? Course makes you think about things, class discussions, fun lectures. Do not take if you are a lazy student for easy A.

How I wish more profs were. So many of my psych profs reads strait from slides and make class completely pointless. Dr. Wright gives good lectures but note taking is necessary. Slides have main points but you can't skip class and read slides as a replacement. Lectures recorded helps. Course content fairly easy but exam have short answer, hard.

Harder than most intro courses but provides critical review of major topics in social psychology. No req. textbook. Attendance not required (no participation points) but necessary if you want to do well, I don't know why people wouldn't as lectures are engaging with connections to current issues.

Theres no question that Dr. Wright is very knowledgeable. The question is whether he can teach this class as an introductory class as it actually is an intro class. He doesnt. Book was mandatory and then it wasnt. His slides have no info. Hes heavy on videos/graphs/articles that should only complement your studies, and not be your main source.

I bought the textbook for this course (which it said was mandatory on the course outline) and we did not need it at all. There goes $70 down the drain. Also, he told us at the beginning of the semester that he tests us about things in his lecture slides, but half of them had no content. Never explained things clearly... terrible professor.

Teaches a very critical approach to psychology compared to the dull reading out of the textbook. Refreshing to hear someone explain how to really understand how to navigate the workings of psychology. People give him a rough time for not uploading lecture slides, but if you actually listen to what he says during lecture it's not to hard to follow.

Clear and usually entertaining lectures. Dr. Wright is very approachable, always talking with students after class. The course can be challenging, he talks fast and presents a lot of data. Often slides don't have a lot on them. No textbook so class is necessary to attend even though no participation marks. Taking his other course next term.

Highly recommend taking 260 with Dr. Wright. Different style than most psyc courses I have taken. Lecture focuses on evidence for theories and prof does a good job weighting pros and cons of different areas. Really enjoyed discussion of video games and violence section. Coming to class def. needed, though does record lectures.

First course that made me think deeply about psych. Dr. Wright is very critical of many studies, doesn't present findings as gold standards, and assignments force you to consider alternative views. Lots of articles to read but no txtbook. Exam require that you can make predictions from theory. Very hard but rewarding course if you can keep up.

Dr. Wright doesn't explain the subject at the 200 level. His lecture approach is more philosophical and based on critical thinking. They are unclear b/c he tends to discuss stuff off subject. You have to thoroughly understand terms and theories because you will be asked to apply them on complicated scenarios on the exam. Midterm average was 64% .

Definitely a difficult course but lectures are great and entertaining. Midterm was tough and expectations are high for the essays. All in all, I learned a lot. He emphasizes critical thinking and often talks about problems within social psychology and times when research conflicts.
Ive genuinely never been graded with this much scrutiny yet with little to no feedback in my entire life

The class with him is a good challenge for upper level students. He has high expectations and really emphasizes research methods and critical thinking. He welcomes criticism and encourages theoretical debate. He's a very engaging speaker, though he can talk fast sometimes. Overall one of the best classes I've taken.
